metadata.titleEn: Quantitative Tescan Integrated Mineral Analyzer (TIMA) data set of tectonite from the North Himalayan Ramba Gneiss Dome
metadata.description:
Data content: This data set is the quantitative comprehensive mineral facies analysis data of tectonite from RAMBA gneiss dome obtained by the Tescan Integrated Mineral Analyzer. The data includes the type, content, structural characteristics, distribution characteristics of the whole mineral facies in the tectonite, as well as the type, abundance and main hosted mineral facies information of the full spectrum elements. 
Data source and processing method: The data were obtained by four high spatial and temporal resolution EDAX energy spectrometers mounted on a Tescan field emission scanning electron microscope. The electrons outside the atomic nucleus of a measuring point on the mineral surface are bombarded by a high-energy electron beam, the transition between different energy levels or excited to escape into free electrons and release photons with a certain energy. The type and content of the mineral element can be accurately calibrated by the signals captured by different energy channels of the energy spectrum detector. Then, automatic comparison and matching are carried out in the database with nearly 5000 mineral phases, so as to fulfill the accurate determination of mineral phases and the element abundance mapping. The voltage is 25 kV, the working distance is 15mm, and the spot size is 100nm.
Data quality description: Due to four energy spectrum detectors being equipped, the data acquisition time is short, the accuracy is high, the requirements for sample morphology are low, the detection limit is low, the data quality is very high and strongly reliable. 
Data application achievements and prospects: Sample size is 27mm x 47mm standard optical thin section, scanning area is full slice scanning with High-resolution scanning mode, and the step size is set to 1μm. Through data analysis, we have obtained the mineral assemblage characteristics of each structural unit of the Ramba gneiss dome, completed the metamorphic grade and metamorphic facies zoning, and put forward the structural thermal evolution model of the Ramba gneiss dome. This technic has been widely recognized and used in structural geology, petrology, geochronology, ore selecting, metallurgy, metal processing and manufacturing, and other disciplines and industries.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the mineral phase data is stored in the specified program format with the name of "xxxx-yyyy.timaproj", where XXXX represents the sampling location and yyyy is the sample number.
Data reading method: this data set contains all quantitative mineral phase analysis data, and the data can only be read and edited by TIMA program officially authorized by tescan company. Tesacn also provides offline processing software, but it can only read data rather than edit it. At the same time, all data can be output in pictures or tables. The output formats include JPG, Tiff, Excel, word, TXT, etc.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the mineral phase analysis data obtained from comprehensive systems in geostructural studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: types of mineral phases, contents of mineral phases, structural characteristics of mineral phases, distribution characteristics of mineral phases, types of full-spectrum elements, abundances of full-spectrum elements, main hosting mineral phase information

Quantification.Question: What is the resolution of data collected using Tescan field emission scanning electron microscope methods for quantifying mineral phases?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary factors that influence the precision and accuracy of mineral phase identification and element abundance measurement in quantitative mineral phase analysis systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The precision and accuracy of mineral phase identification and element abundance measurement are influenced by several factors, including the use of high spatial and temporal resolution EDAX spectrometers equipped on a Tescan field emission scanning electron microscope. The setup involves a specific test voltage, working distance, and beam spot size, which contribute to the high precision and low detection limits. Additionally, the ability to automatically match and compare results against a comprehensive database of nearly 5000 mineral phases also significantly affects the accuracy of the analysis.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using high-resolution EDAX spectrometers for mineral phase analysis in terms of data accuracy and sample integrity?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-resolution EDAX spectrometers has resulted in high data accuracy due to the precision in capturing signals across different energy channels, which accurately identifies mineral element types and quantities. The method also supports high sample integrity, as it requires low sample surface morphology requirements and has a low detection limit, ensuring high-quality data with strong reliability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting and analyzing mineral phase data using a comprehensive mineral phase analysis system in the context of the Ranba gneiss dome structures?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include determining the mineral assemblage characteristics of various structural layers within the Ranba gneiss dome, completing the metamorphic grade and facies zoning work, and proposing a thermal evolution model for the Ranba gneiss dome structure. This comprehensive analysis aids in understanding the geological, metamorphic, and chronological features of the area, which has applications in structural geology, metamorphic petrology, geochronology, and industries like mineral sorting, metallurgy, and metal processing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be employed to effectively utilize scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy for comprehensive mineral phase analysis in geological samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using a Tescan field emission scanning electron microscope equipped with four high spatial and temporal resolution EDAX spectrometers. The process includes bombarding the mineral surface with a high-energy electron beam, causing outer-shell electrons to transition between energy levels or be ejected as free electrons. This transition releases photons with specific energy, which are captured by the spectrometers' energy channels to accurately determine the mineral's elemental composition and abundance. These results are then matched against a database of nearly 5000 mineral phases to achieve precise mineral phase determination and element abundance mapping. The testing voltage is set at 25kV, the working distance is 15mm, and the beam spot size is 100nm.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the precise determination of mineral phases and element abundance distribution in complex geological structures such as gneiss domes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a Tescan field emission scanning electron microscope equipped with four high spatial and temporal resolution EDAX spectrometers has enabled the precise determination of mineral phases and element abundance distribution. The system captures signals through energy spectrometry to accurately identify mineral element types and content, allowing for automatic comparison and matching with a database containing nearly 5000 mineral phases.
